trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of tramadol analgesia on post-operative ventilation duration in post-surgical neonates
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Impact on post-operative newborn infants receiving tramadol or placebo on duration of mechanical ventilation

conditions.healthcondition: Need for mechanical ventilation in post-surgical neonates

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Conditions of unknown or disputed aetiology (such as chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis)

interventions.interventions: Administration of tramadol infusion 2 mg/kg (in 10 mls) every six hours for five days commencing immediately post-operatively.
interventions.comparator: normal saline placebo administered intravenously 10 mls given every six hours for five days, commenced post-operatively

primaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of mechanical ventilation measured in hours

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Impact on amplitude integrated electroencophalography (aEEG) of tramadol versus placebo. aEEG will be assessed visually with reader blinded to treatment group. Outcome is presence of seizure activity
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: aEEG will be recorded continuously until extubation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Newborn infants requiring surgery at The Royal Children's Hospital who are inpatients on the Newborn Intensive Care Unit.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Infants born less < 32 weeks' gestation or infants with congenital malformations of the nervous system.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Tramadol is increasingly used as an analgesic in newborn infants who require surgery. It is hypothesised that tramadol use promotes decreased exposure to other analgesic agents like morphine, some of which depress respiration. By measuring the effect of tramadol or placebo on duration of mechanical ventilation, we can determine whether or not using tramadol has a significant sparing effect for the use of opioid analgesic agents.
